title: Kenya: Unions Ordered to Call Off Strike Immediately
text:
Nigeria: Workers, Students, Others Protest in Ekiti, Ondo, Osun By Abiud Ochieng 
Teachers unions suffered a major setback after a court ordered them to call off their month-long strike immediately. 
Labour Court Judge Nelson Abuodha said he had last Friday ordered the unions to suspend the strike for 90 days and start negotiations with the government on the pay dispute. 
The judge had directed the Kenya National Union of Teachers and Kenya Union of Post Primary Education Teachers to form a committee with the Labour Cabinet secretary to discuss how best to implement the June 30 salary award of between 50 and 60 per cent. 
"I plead with the union officials to advise their members to respect the orders of this court of September 25, as they will need its protection tomorrow as they always have," Justice Abuodha said. 
The unions had asked him to stop the requirement that teachers resume teaching since there is an ongoing appeal at the Court of Appeal challenging the higher salaries awarded to the teachers. 
At the Court of Appeal, union lawyers Paul Muite, Kioko Kilukumi, Judith Guserwa and John Mbaluto told the five-judge bench that the teachers' employer is always quick to rush to court claiming the strike is illegal but fails to tackle the pay issue. 
PROBLEM SOLVED 
Mr Muite told Judges Erastus Githinji, Philomena Mwilu, Festus Azangalala, Prof James Odek Otieno and Martha Koome that Mr Justice Nduma Nderi of the Labour Court, who awarded the teachers the salary increase, had finally resolved the perennial problem, which had caused strikes since 1997. 
He also said the Teachers Service Commission and the government have failed to appreciate that teachers are overworked due to the free primary education that created an upsurge in school enrolment. 
"The standard requirement of teacher-student ratio is 1 to 25 but teachers, especially in primary schools, are teaching a class of more than 90 pupils," he said. 
Mr Kilukumi said the unions had called off the strike in January this year and left the pay rise issue to the court. 
"The court awarded them the 50-60 per cent rise, which their employer has now blatantly refused to pay," Mr Kilukumi said. 
He urged the Court of Appeal to direct the government to start paying the award as a condition for its appeal to be heard. 
Mrs Guserwa accused the commission of holding 26 meetings with the unions which yielded nothing, hence the strike. 
The hearing resumes on Monday. Kenya
